liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Emilie Gramenz in Washington DC Meanwhile, in a separate case, a federal judge has ruled the writer E Jean Carroll can pursue Donald Trump for more damages, after her successful defamation case against him. Last month a jury found Trump liable for sexually abusing Carroll in the 1990s and later defaming her by lying about it. He was ordered to pay her $US5 million ($7.5 million). A Manhattan judge has now said Carroll can amend her original lawsuit to include comments Trump made in a CNN Town Hall after the verdict - which allows her to seek additional damages. In the live event, Trump reiterated his criticism of Carroll. He’s also appearing the jury’s verdict.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: More bad news for Trump today

children.content: Reporting by Emilie Gramenz in Washington DC
Meanwhile, in a separate case, a federal judge has ruled the writer E Jean Carroll can pursue Donald Trump for more damages, after her successful defamation case against him.
Last month a jury found Trump liable for sexually abusing Carroll in the 1990s and later defaming her by lying about it.

props.alt: E Jean Carroll exits the Manhattan Federal Court.

children.content: E Jean Carroll (centre) exits the Manhattan Federal Court following the verdict in the civil rape accusation case against Trump last month.
(Reuters: David Dee Delgado/File)
He was ordered to pay her $US5 million ($7.5 million).
A Manhattan judge has now said Carroll can amend her original lawsuit to include comments Trump made in a CNN Town Hall after the verdict - which allows her to seek additional damages.
In the live event, Trump reiterated his criticism of Carroll.
He’s also appearing the jury’s verdict.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By North America bureau chief Jade Macmillan in Washington DC President Joe Biden has rejected Donald Trump’s claims that the case against him is politically motivated, with White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre seeking to reinforce that message again today. “I’m just not going to comment on anything that’s related to the indictment,” she says. "We’re just going to be very mindful here and respect the Department of Justice, let them do their job.” Biden has previously insisted that he had never sought to influence the DOJ, and his Attorney-General appointed special counsel Jack Smith to try to keep Mr Trump’s case at arm's length. But that won’t stop the former president and his supporters from characterising the investigation as a witch hunt and an attempt to interfere in the 2024 election. Trump is still considered the leading candidate for the Republican presidential nomination, while Biden has declared that he’s also running for office again.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The White House has sought to distance itself from the case

children.content: By North America bureau chief Jade Macmillan in Washington DC

President Joe Biden has rejected Donald Trump’s claims that the case against him is politically motivated, with White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre seeking to reinforce that message again today.
“I’m just not going to comment on anything that’s related to the indictment,” she says.
"We’re just going to be very mindful here and respect the Department of Justice, let them do their job.”
Biden has previously insisted that he had never sought to influence the DOJ, and his Attorney-General appointed special counsel Jack Smith to try to keep Mr Trump’s case at arm's length.
But that won’t stop the former president and his supporters from characterising the investigation as a witch hunt and an attempt to interfere in the 2024 election.
Trump is still considered the leading candidate for the Republican presidential nomination, while Biden has declared that he’s also running for office again.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Police are urgently searching for a day-old baby girl who was taken from a hospital and may be at significant risk. Two women were seen taking the baby from Ipswich Hospital on Monday and putting her into a white Suzuki, which has since been located. An Amber Alert has been issued. Queensland Police Commissioner Katarina Carroll told ABC Radio Brisbane this morning that detectives are looking for the baby's mother 18-year-old Khloe Bornen, who is believed to be with the baby. "We have many detectives, many uniform officers … just not patrolling and looking and investigating but searching on social media. "I call upon the public — if you can, if you know anything, please contact police." Khloe is described as Caucasian and around 165 centimetres tall with a proportionate build and brown hair. Police urged anyone with information to call 131 564, or triple-0 if the details are life-threatening. West Moreton Health chief executive Hannah Bloch in a statement said the baby was not taken by a "third party". "The mother discharged herself and her child soon after giving birth," she said. "I am disclosing this information in the public interest so women can continue to feel safe giving birth at Ipswich Hospital. "This was an isolated incident and the healthcare provided to mother and baby is not in question."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Search for Queensland mother and newborn continues

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Transgender advocate Rose Montoya is no longer welcome at White House events after posting on social media a video of herself going topless for a time at Saturday's Pride Month celebration on the South Lawn. "The behavior was simply unacceptable," White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre says. "It was unfair to the hundreds of attendees who were there to celebrate their families." US President Joe Biden hosted the event to show the administration's support of the LGBTQ+ community. Montoya has defended her post on Instagram and Twitter, saying that "going topless in Washington, DC is legal and I fully support the movement in freeing the nipple". She says critics of her toplessness affirms that she is, in fact, a woman, as a man would not face similar pushback. She says she had "zero intention of trying to be vulgar or be profane in anyway", adding that she covered her nipples with her hands in the video "just to play it safe". Montoya says she will be making a public statement on the situation "soon".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: White House bans transgender advocate who went topless at Biden event

children.content: Transgender advocate Rose Montoya is no longer welcome at White House events after posting on social media a video of herself going topless for a time at Saturday's Pride Month celebration on the South Lawn.
"The behavior was simply unacceptable," White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre says.
"It was unfair to the hundreds of attendees who were there to celebrate their families."
US President Joe Biden hosted the event to show the administration's support of the LGBTQ+ community.

props.alt: A woman smiles next to Joe Biden, who smiles and wears a suit and sunglasses

She says critics of her toplessness affirms that she is, in fact, a woman, as a man would not face similar pushback.
She says she had "zero intention of trying to be vulgar or be profane in anyway", adding that she
covered her nipples with her hands in the video "just to play it safe"
Montoya says she will be making a public statement on the situation "soon".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Avatar: The Way of Water may have already hit cinemas, but the long parade of Avatar delays isn't done yet. The Walt Disney Company has pushed the release of Avatar 3 back by a a year, bumping it from December 2024 to December 2025. The timeline is stretched even further for the next planned installments. Avatar 4 is now slated to hit theatres in December 2029, with Avatar 5 set to arrive in December 2031! If those dates hold, the Avatar film series will have stretched across the first four decades of the century. Director James Cameron, who launched Avatar in 2009, has said he may not direct films 4 and 5. By December 2031, the 68-year-old would be 77. Avatar and Avatar: The Way of Water have collectively made more than $US5.2 billion ($7.7 billion) at the box office .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Disney pushes Avatar 3 back to the end of 2025, delays other sequels

props.alt: Avatar characters Neytiri, right, and Jake in a scene from the 2009 movie.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The banking and financial services regulator APRA is fining OnePath Custodians almost $1.5 million dollars. The regulator says OnePath failed to direct member funds to low cost MySuper products, which are supposed to be the default option when someone doesn't advise where they would like their money invested. OnePath is a superannuation trustee owned by Insignia Financial, previously known as IOOF, and has approximately 700,000 members and $35 billion in funds under management. It has been hit with infringement notices totalling $1.46 million for failing to direct 125 member contributions to a MySuper product from mid-last year onwards. "In addition to today's enforcement action, APRA is closely monitoring OPC to ensure any members who suffered financial losses as a result of these breaches are fully compensated as soon as possible," APRA Deputy Chair Margaret Cole said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Super fund fined for not putting member funds in no-frills accounts

children.content: The banking and financial services regulator APRA is fining OnePath Custodians almost $1.5 million dollars.

The regulator says OnePath failed to direct member funds to low cost MySuper products, which are supposed to be the default option when someone doesn't advise where they would like their money invested.
OnePath is a superannuation trustee owned by Insignia Financial, previously known as IOOF, and has approximately 700,000 members and $35
billion in funds under management.
It has been hit with infringement notices totalling $1.46 million for failing to direct 125 member contributions to a MySuper product from mid-last year onwards.

"In addition to today's enforcement action, APRA is closely monitoring OPC to ensure any members who suffered financial losses as a result of these breaches are fully compensated as soon as possible," APRA Deputy Chair Margaret Cole said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As rising rates reduce people's borrowing capacities, there are warnings it could lead to more misrepresentations in home loan applications. So-called 'liar loans' have involved loan applicants or brokers inflating incomes or fudging other details on loan documents. It's still an issue, warns Profession of Independent Financial Advisers president Daniel Brammall, who does not believe banks have stopped approving loans without proper verification checks, and says rising interest rates will test the strength of loan books. In one case, Elisabetta Di Nardo has spent two years trying to hold ANZ bank to account for failing to verify documents provided in her home loan application. Ms Di Nardo is now pursuing the bank through the Australian Financial Complaints Authority. "We continue to actively engage with AFCA during this process," a spokeswoman for ANZ said in a statement. Find out more here in this story from Rhiana Whitson :
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Warnings misrepresented loans could grow as rates rise

featuredLink.title: Elisabetta says ANZ failed to verify her home loan application, she's taking it to court

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's the reason behind the share market rally overnight, so just what did the latest US inflation report show? In May, consumer prices rose just 0.1 per cent, according the the US Bureau of Labor Statistics — down from 0.4 per cent in April. That brings the annual inflation rate to 4 per cent, the smallest rise since March 2021. Energy prices decreased substantially, but housing and used car costs rose, along with food prices, after being unchanged for the previous two months. Core inflation edged just slightly lower, to 5.3 per cent annually. The Federal Reserve was already tipped to pause its interest rate rises at its meeting this week, and expectations of no change to rates increased after the inflation report.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Smallest annual increase in US inflation in 2+ years

children.content: It's the reason behind the share market rally overnight, so just what did the latest US inflation report show?
In May, consumer prices rose just 0.1 per cent, according the the US Bureau of Labor Statistics — down from 0.4 per cent in April.
That brings the annual inflation rate to 4 per cent, the smallest rise since March 2021.
Energy prices decreased substantially, but housing and used car costs rose, along with food prices, after being unchanged for the previous two months.
Core inflation edged just slightly lower, to 5.3 per cent annually.
The Federal Reserve was already tipped to pause its interest rate rises at its meeting this week, and expectations of no change to rates increased after the inflation report.
